newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Risk to oil supplies deterrent to U.S. attack - Iran.
newsitem.headline: Risk to oil supplies deterrent to U.S. attack - Iran.

text.p: Iran does not expect the United States to seek a military confrontation with the Islamic republic because such a move would jeopardise oil exports from the region, an Iranian official was quoted on Thursday as saying.

"I do not think America would have, for the time being, any intention to start any confrontation, because it would not be in its interest to jeopardise the oil (shipping) route," Kuwait's al-Anba newspaper quoted visiting Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister Hossein Sheikholeslam as saying.
"No one has an interest in threatening (regional) security and the security of the oil supplies in the Gulf," he said.
The United States and its Gulf Arab allies have repeatedly said Iran's arms programme poses a threat to the region which sits on around 70 percent of the world's known oil reserves.

Iran's spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei last month said U.S. media reports alleging an Iranian role in a June bomb attack that killed 19 U.S. airmen in Saudi Arabia and a possible U.S. military retaliation for that indicated that Washington was preparing to launch an attack on Iran.
Iran, the region's non-Arab power, is strategically placed at the entrance to the Gulf, the narrow Strait of Hormuz, through which 15 million barrels of oil pass each day.

Asked if Iran would block the strait in case of a military clash, Sheikholeslam said: "I do not foresee confrontation...if it happens I cannot envisage what we would do. Had we had such plans I do not believe we would disclose them."
He reiterated his country's stand that it did not pose any threat to the region's security.
